channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Thousands in Iran Protest Acid Attacks on Women
item.description: Demonstrations in Isfahan erupted after assaults that coincided with the passage of a law designed to protect those who correct people deemed to be acting in an “un-Islamic” way.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Demonstrators in the historic city of Isfahan on Wednesday shouted slogans against militants.

item.title: Open Source: Lohan’s Unlikely Endorsement of Neves in Brazil Elections
item.description: A unusual Twitter message posted in the actress’s name was pulled after stirring suspicions, and mockery.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of a message posted on the Twitter account of Lindsay Lohan on Tuesday.

item.title: Driver Plows Into Group at Jerusalem Train Station, Killing Baby, Police Say
item.description: The driver was shot by police officers as he tried to flee, according to the Israeli police, in what was being treated as a terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Altay Journal: In China, a Drought Tests Nomadic Herders’ Culture of Survival
item.description: A devastating drought in the Xinjiang region has disturbed an ancient tradition of producing prized animals known for their hefty tails.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A herder named Aijamal overseeing her family’s sheep on the move to winter pastures.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Man Sought by Danes Is Freed
item.description: Turkey has freed Basil Hassan, who is wanted by Denmark in the attempted murder of a prominent critic of Islam, Turkish officials said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Estonia: Tensions Over a Russian Jet
item.description: A Russian military surveillance airplane crossed into Estonia’s airspace and was intercepted by NATO jets, the Estonian Foreign Ministry’s spokeswoman said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Band Member Is Found Dead
item.description: Aldo Sarabia, a member of Banda el Recodo was found dead on Wednesday in the northwestern resort city of Mazatlan with at least one gunshot wound, the group and local officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Marine’s Arrest in Killing in Philippines May Test Ties
item.description: Some Philippine senators cited the case in calling for a review of the accord setting the rules under which American military forces visit the country.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: Protesters outside the United States embassy in Manila on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: Charity Closes After Scandal
item.description: The Somaly Mam Foundation, which worked against human trafficking and sexual exploitation, has closed five months after its founder resigned amid allegations of broad deception.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Arrest in Case of Dead Babies
item.description: The Canadian police said that they had charged a woman with concealing the bodies of six infants in a storage locker, but that they were not considering it a homicide.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Confucian, Stubborn and Macho: China’s Leader is ‘Xi Bigbig’
item.description: Xi Jinping, China’s head of state, the Communist Party and the military, is acquiring nicknames and descriptions among the Chinese people as his rule progresses. Some are affectionate, others are not.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping arriving for the National Day reception at the Great Hall of the People marking the 65th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China on Oct. 1.

item.title: World Briefing: Northern Ireland Orders Inquiry Into Handling of Rape Allegations
item.description: The investigation will look at prosecutors’ handling of allegations by a woman that she was raped by a senior I.R.A. member, then interrogated in “kangaroo courts.”
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Canadian Soldier Dead After Attack Near Parliament in Ottawa
item.description: A gunman fatally wounded a soldier guarding the National War Memorial, entered the Parliament building and fired multiple times before he was shot and killed.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: For Swiss, a Distasteful Jolt With Coffee: Hitler Creamer
item.description: The company, Migros, said it was “unforgivable” that images of Hitler and Mussolini had appeared on containers that usually feature Alpine landscapes and animals.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Turkish Leader Says U.S. Airdrop Aided Militants
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the Islamic State had seized some weapons and supplies intended for Kurdish fighters in the Syrian town of Kobani.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Kim Jong-un Gave Order to Free American, North Korea Says
item.description: North Korea said its leader had ordered the release of Jeffrey E. Fowle, one of three Americans recently detained there, after requests from President Obama.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jeffrey E. Fowle was greeted by family members at an Ohio Air Force base on Wednesday.

item.title: Museum of the History of Polish Jews in Warsaw to Unveil Core Exhibition
item.description: An exhibition in Warsaw, occupying eight sprawling galleries, traces the history of Jews from their first appearance in Poland in the Middle Ages to the present day.
item.category: Museum of the History of Polish Jews
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Museum of the History of Polish Jews in Warsaw.

item.title: Lens Blog: Revisiting Unhealed Wounds in Chechnya
item.description: Stanley Greene returned to Chechnya to document the aftermath of the 1993 conflict, and his photographs were gathered into a book, “Open Wound.”
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: On his visit to Chechnya, Mr. Greene found posters of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the Chechen leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, in many places. The National Theater, Grozny, Chechnya. 2013.

item.title: Thierry Desmarest and Patrick Pouyanné to Lead Oil Giant Total After Chief’s Death
item.description: The company is splitting its chief executive and chairman jobs, bringing back a former chief, with a plan for Mr. Pouyanné to lead it into 2016.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY and STANLEY REED

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Yan Lianke on Writing in China
item.description: From the shadows I lift my pen to write. I search for love, goodness and a perpetually beating heart.
item.dc:creator: By YAN LIANKE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Estimated 2,400 Executions Last Year Put China Far Off Peak
item.description: The estimated number of executions compares with about 12,000 in 2002, according to a United States-based human rights organization.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Jiang Jiatin, accused of leading a criminal gang, listened as he was sentenced to death in a court in Kunming, Yunnan Province, in 2009.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Putting on Its Shiniest Face for Economic Summit
item.description: Now that China is the world’s second-largest economy, its leaders have proved willing to throw some cash around to ensure this year’s APEC summit meeting fully represents the country’s transformation into an economic giant and important geopolitical player.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: A Hongqi L5 limousine was parked outside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing during a welcoming ceremony for Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain last December.

item.title: New Commissioners Approved for E.U.’s Executive Branch
item.description: The vote by lawmakers ended months of sometimes acrimonious debate over the administrative direction of the 28-nation bloc.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Jean-Claude Juncker, the incoming president of the European Commission, in a speech before the European Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Beijing Unsoothed by a Kenny G Visit
item.description: The musician is hugely popular in China, and Beijing did not appreciate his getting involved in the pro-democracy demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Tempest Over a Chamber Pot as Taiwan Scrutinizes Chinese Tourists’ Manners
item.description: A recent report that Chinese tourists allowed their 3-year-old child to urinate in an upscale Taipei restaurant has raised complaints in Taiwan about the behavior of mainland visitors.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
